Award.AwardTitle: Inferring Biological Relatedness And Genomic Ancestry Using 2nd Generation Sequencing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Krishna Veeramah of Stony Brook University and Patrick Geary of the Institute for Advanced Study will use advanced ancient DNA analysis to clarify the nature of the medieval "barbarian" societies from which many modern-day Europeans still trace their national identities. The degree to which biological relationships shape the social organization of human groups has been a major area of research across many fields. Understanding these dynamics in past non-state societies matters because many modern nations claim these earlier polities as their own historical identities. However, written texts and cultural artifacts such as weapons, jewelry, and clothing are at best ambiguous sources for understanding this past. DNA from burials potentially offers new biological information that, when combined with more traditional archeological and written data, can substantially increase our understanding of the social structures of past peoples. In particular, 2nd generation sequencing is revolutionizing the ability to interrogate DNA from ancient samples, though until now its application has been limited to questions regarding hominin prehistory.

Between the fifth and seventh centuries Western Europe experienced the disappearance of the Roman Empire and along with it a fundamental transformation of economic, social, and cultural patterns. Migrating barbarian groups are thought to have played an important role in this transformation and scholars have long debated their social structures. It is uncertain whether these were communities that had long maintained social and cultural cohesion or if they were heterogeneous ad hoc military groups. The migration of the Lombards from Pannonia (what is now Western Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Eastern Austria) into Italy in 568 C.E. represents one of the most historically documented migrations and one for which there is a relative abundance of putative archaeological material. Veeramah, Geary and colleagues will generate genomic level data from a key Lombard era cemetery in Szólád, Hungary. Forty-six burials at this fully excavated site will undergo DNA extraction followed by whole mitochondrial (mtDNA) sequencing. Those burials for which mtDNA sequencing is successful will then undergo sequencing at approximately 390,000 sites from across the genome. This will allow inference of genetic relatedness between burials down to at least third degree relatives. Standard statistical methods will test whether relatedness is associated with the spatial arrangement of burials, and genomic ancestry will be correlated with other archaeological data to develop a high-resolution conceptual model of social organization, hierarchies, and gender relationships. Besides illuminating the structure of this specific community, the results will contribute to the development of new approaches to the application of genomic analysis of historical populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this proposal was to generate genomic level data from skeletal remains found in a 6th century Lombard-era cemetery in Szólád, Hungary, in order to better understand the social system of the past people that it represents. More specifically this study attempted to a) characterize the genomes of multiple individuals buried at Szólád, b) test whether genetic relatedness is associated with the spatial structuring of burials and c) develop a high-resolution conceptual model of social organization, hierarchies, and gender relationships.

Overall genomic data was successfully generated for 36 (~81%) of the burials at Szólád, with 10 samples undergoing high-medium coverage whole genome sequencing and the remaining samples undergoing a novel capture-array that targeted 1.2 million single nucleotide polymorphisms. In addition, genomic data was obtained for 23 (~50%) burials from another Lombard-era cemetery, this time from Collegno, near Turin in Italy, which is hypothesized to be one of the earliest Lombard cemeteries following their migration into Italy.

Using a new method for inferring biological relatedness, clear biological kinship groups were identified in both cemeteries.  Four biological kindred were found in Szólád. In particular one kindred contained 10 individuals and spanned 3 generations. This kindred appeared to be very prominent in the cemetery, with almost all individuals being buried in close proximity to each other in the northwest of the cemetery. There is a notable absence of women in the this pedigree, and in particular of mothers or aunts of any of the children. Overall, Szólád appears to be organized around this high status male-biased kin group, and clearly biological kinship is an important part of social organization more generally. Biological kinship was also found to be important in Collegno. This is the first time that such exact genealogical relationships have been determined at an archaeological site. Future studies using a similar approach will be needed to determine the extent to which these patterns will emerge in cemeteries involving other peoples and time periods.

In addition, individuals in Szólád were generally divided into those with ancestry that today is present in northern Europe and those with more southern Europe ancestry. There is a significant relationship between various aspects of material culture and which ancestry group an individual belonged to. Interestingly the same relationship was also seen in Collegno. This striking correlation between material culture and genetic ancestry has never been observed before (primarily because there has yet to be such a dense genomic sampling of a single cemetery) and is likely to have major implications for thinking about how population genetic structure and archaeology interact in the future.

Finally, the northern ancestry component found to be prominent in both Szólád and Collegno was found to not be common in Hungary (or Italy) today, nor in these regions in the Bronze Age. However, it does appear to closely match the ancestry type found in Bronze Age individuals from Germany and Scandinavia. While further data will be required from other surrounding cemeteries and time periods to confirm patterns of background population genetic structure, these results appear to be consistent with the idea of people moving from the north into the former Roman Empire.
